security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only a SKILL.md file with logging pattern guidelines. No executable code, network operations, file access, or system capabilities. This is a safe, read-only reference skill.

content.user_title: Add structured logging with correlation IDs
content.value_statement: Distributed systems generate logs across multiple services making debugging difficult. This skill provides a standardized logging format with correlation IDs that link related log entries across service boundaries.
actual_capabilities: Generate correlation IDs with standardized prefixes for different operation types
Format log entries as structured JSON with timestamp, level, and context
Propagate correlation IDs across services via HTTP headers
Define log levels for different scenarios (ERROR, WARN, INFO, DEBUG)
limitations: This is a documentation skill - it provides guidelines but does not implement actual logging code
No file I/O or log storage capabilities
No built-in log aggregation or analysis features
Does not integrate with specific logging services or platforms

prompt_templates.title: Basic Logging Setup
prompt_templates.scenario: Adding logging to a new service
prompt_templates.prompt: Add structured logging with correlation IDs to my service. Use the error-logger pattern with JSON format and include timestamp, level, correlation_id, service name, event_type, message, and context fields.

prompt_templates.title: Correlation ID Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up correlation ID generation for my operations. Create a function that generates IDs with format prefix_timestamp_hex_random using liq_, arb_, quo_, or op_ prefixes.

prompt_templates.title: Cross-Service Tracing
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement X-Correlation-ID header propagation across my microservices. Show how to extract the header on incoming requests and attach it to outgoing HTTP calls.

prompt_templates.title: Error Handling Integration
prompt_templates.prompt: Add error logging to my error handlers. Log the error type, message, stack trace, transaction hash, and gas used as structured context data with a correlation ID.

output_examples.input: Add error logging to my liquidation service with correlation IDs
output: Next: Propagate via X-Correlation-ID header to downstream services

best_practices: Include correlation ID in every log entry for a request to enable full trace reconstruction
Use consistent prefixes (liq_, arb_, quo_, op_) to quickly identify operation types
Attach rich context data including transaction hashes, user IDs, and calculation details
Propagate correlation IDs via HTTP headers when calling downstream services
anti_patterns: Logging without correlation IDs - makes tracing requests across services impossible
Using unstructured free-text messages instead of JSON format
Missing timestamp or service name in log entries
Not propagating correlation ID to downstream service calls

faq.question: Which platforms support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. It provides guidelines that apply to any programming language.

faq.question: What is the maximum log entry size?
faq.answer: There is no fixed limit. Include as much context as needed but avoid extremely large nested objects in the context field.

faq.question: How do I integrate with existing logging systems?
faq.answer: The skill provides a format specification. Output JSON logs to stdout or your existing log collector. Most platforms can parse JSON-formatted logs.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this logging pattern?
faq.answer: This is a documentation pattern. You control what data goes into logs. Avoid logging passwords, tokens, or sensitive user data.

faq.question: Logs are not appearing in my service - what to check?
faq.answer: Verify you are using the correct correlation ID format, including it in all related log entries, and that your log output destination is properly configured.

faq.question: How does this compare to OpenTelemetry tracing?
faq.answer: This provides a simpler, lightweight alternative for correlation-based tracing. For full distributed tracing with spans, consider OpenTelemetry as a more comprehensive solution.
